column4: My guess is that eth0 and eth1 have existed at some previous point. During the boot sequence, maybe?
can you please tell me how i can figure it out?
Is this the same question as before? Otherwise, please clarify.

yup - it's the same. mroe details: my system is virtual ubuntu-server-9.04 on ms cluster & cluster admins in 2 last days reconfigured some architecture so my ubu system have changed MACs twice. I suppose that system have some kind of autoconf because of that & this *auto* was wrong. i don't want to store my old MACs, i just need to use the current as eth0
At the risk of sounding like a Windows user: Have you tried rebooting?
sure ))) (in fact i'm doing this winmagic regulary) but let me try again.
Which version of Ubuntu are you using?
Maybe /etc/network/interfaces is misconfigured?

nope - it's quite right (worked perfect before). I think it's because of /etc/udev/rules.d/70-persistent-net.rules - i have all my old MACs and eth* there + current one. I'll try to comment wrong lines & restart again
That sounds good.
strange that i didn't googled it in english inet... only 1 russian blog. usually it's tottaly different )
I didnt't even remember that file... Do you know when and how it is created/updated?
i suppose it was created during system start when device-searching-scripts working
Or just once during system install. I'll try to figure it out...
well... i'll be glad to be sure where this file come from
You might have to hang around for the answer, though. I don't think I'll get to it right away.
oh, i didnt's said but my system on-air now )) it was right file
Oops, I should have taken a better look at that file. The first comment states how it is generated...
oops yeah ^_^ i was too busy with configuring to read the header
Then again, do you have that file (75-persistent-net-generator.rules)? I don't seem to. (Currently using a live CD, though. Maybe that's why.)
no or it's somwhere else on FS. it's not in that dir
Here it is: /lib/udev/rules.d/75-persistent-net-generator.rules
